docs.lead_paragraph: Young Americans are more likely to favor an open-door policy on immigration, the legalization of gay marriage and government-run health care, a poll found.

headline.main: Young Americans Are Leaning Left, New Poll Finds
headline.sub: Universal Health Plan Is Backed — Many Expect Success in Iraq;
headline.print_headline: Young Americans Are Leaning Left, New Poll Finds

docs.snippet: Young Americans are more likely to favor an open-door policy on immigration, the legalization of gay marriage and government-run health care, a poll found.

byline.contributor: Marjorie Connelly, Marina Stefan and Dalia Sussman contributed reporting.
byline.original: By ADAM NAGOURNEY and MEGAN  THEE

docs.lead_paragraph: The Kurdish region of Iraq is hoping to challenge Dubai as the Middle East’s main transportation and business hub.

docs.lead_paragraph: Charging workers out-of-pocket costs for medicines may be more than offset by reduced productivity, a study found.

docs.lead_paragraph: It can be tempting to think of labor unions as an antagonistic relic of an industrial economy and to forget about their lingering impact.

docs.lead_paragraph: A headline on an article in Business Day on Saturday about the efforts of some companies to provide health insurance for retirees too young for Medicare overstated the number of retirees the program might help. Although about 800,000 early retirees are said to be without health insurance, the program's organizers say the plan would probably help only a fraction of them, not all.
docs.abstract: Correction of headline of June 23 article about companies that provide health insurance to retirees who are too young for Medicare, regarding number of retirees program might help

docs.lead_paragraph: Young Americans appear to lean slightly more to the left than the general population, according to a new poll.

headline.main: Poll Shows Liberal Ideas Gaining With Young People

docs.snippet: Young Americans appear to lean slightly more to the left than the general population, according to a new poll.

docs.lead_paragraph: The federal government deserves a pat on the back for identifying hospitals that have the best and worst mortality rates for cardiac patients. Unfortunately, the ratings are too broad to help most patients.

docs.lead_paragraph: About 14.8 percent of the American population had no health insurance in 2006, according to a survey.
